questions.question_text: What is a distributed system?

options.B: A system with a global clock
options.C: A system that does not allow communication between nodes
options.D: A collection of autonomous computing elements that appear as a single coherent system

questions.question_text: What is a characteristic feature of a distributed system?
What is an overlay network in a distributed system?

options.B: A virtual or logical network created on top of an existing physical network
options.C: A network with no communication paths
options.D: A network with a single node

questions.question_text: What is a structured overlay network?

options.A: A network where each node has a well-defined set of neighbors
options.B: A network where nodes have randomly selected neighbors
options.C: A network with no communication paths
options.D: A network with a single node

questions.question_text: What is an unstructured overlay network?

options.A: A network where each node has a well-defined set of neighbors
options.B: A network where nodes have randomly selected neighbors
options.C: A network with no communication paths
options.D: A network with a single node

questions.question_text: What is a partial failure in a distributed system?

options.A: A failure where the entire system stops working
options.B: A failure where no nodes are affected
options.C: A failure where communication is always maintained
options.D: A failure where only a part of the system fails

questions.question_text: What is an open group in a distributed system?

options.A: A group where only specific nodes can join
options.C: A group where any node is allowed to join and communicate
options.D: A group with a single node

questions.question_text: What is the main challenge in synchronizing distributed systems?

options.A: The presence of a global clock
options.B: The lack of a global clock
options.C: The inability of nodes to communicate

questions.question_text: In a distributed system, nodes operate independently and can exchange information.
A distributed system requires a global clock for synchronization.
An overlay network is a physical network.
Peer-to-peer systems are an example of an overlay network.
In a structured overlay network, nodes have randomly selected neighbors.
In an open group, any node is allowed to join and communicate.
In a closed group, only specific nodes can communicate with each other.
What is the primary purpose of middleware in a distributed system?

options.B: To facilitate communication and integration between distributed components
options.D: To reduce the need for networking

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of Message-Oriented Middleware (MOM)?

options.A: A distributed e-commerce system with asynchronous communication

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key characteristic of a distributed system?
What is the main goal of resource sharing in a distributed system?

options.B: To reduce the need for networking
options.D: To facilitate users' access to remote resources

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a Peer-to-Peer (P2P) network?
What does 'openness' in a distributed system refer to?

options.A: The ability to extend and improve hardware and software components
options.B: The ability to limit access to resources

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a scalability dimension in distributed systems?
What is the purpose of caching in a distributed system?

options.C: To store frequently accessed data closer to users

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a distributed file system?
Creating copies of data or resources across multiple nodes to ensure data availability
Middleware acts as an intermediary between different software applications in a distributed system.
As an example for middleware, Message-Oriented Middleware (MOM) is used for synchronous communication in distributed systems.
Resource sharing in a distributed system is limited to computational resources only.
Peer-to-Peer (P2P) networks rely on centralized servers for resource sharing.
Openness in a distributed system refers to the ability to add or remove components without compatibility issues.
Caching in a distributed system is used to reduce latency and improve responsiveness.
Within the distributed system, the performance of tasks will be faster than the parallel system
In the parallel system, the processors need to apply a synchronization algorithm
One of the advantages of a distributed system is the shared memory between its elements
What is the primary goal of distribution transparency in a distributed system?

options.B: To hide system intricacies and present the system as a single coherent system
options.C: To reduce the need for networking

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a challenge in achieving full distribution transparency?

options.C: Replicas are always up to date with the master
options.D: Failures are easy to distinguish from slow systems

questions.question_text: What is utility computing?

options.A: A model where computing resources are provided as needed and charged based on usage
options.B: A model where computing resources are provided at a flat rate
options.C: A model where computing resources are only available locally
options.D: A model where computing resources are not accessible over the internet

questions.question_text: What is grid computing primarily targeted at?
Which of the following is an example of Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)?
What is the key feature of Platform as a Service (PaaS)?

options.B: Provides a development platform with tools and libraries
options.C: Delivers software applications over the internet

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of Software as a Service (SaaS)?
What is the primary feature of Software as a Service (SaaS)?

options.B: Offers web-based access and automatic updates

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key milestone in the evolution of cloud computing?

options.A: The invention of the personal computer
options.B: The introduction of utility computing in the 1960s
options.C: The development of local area networks (LANs)
options.D: The creation of the first operating system

questions.question_text: The mobile communication within different locations can be seen as an example for
Distribution transparency aims to hide the complexities of a distributed system.
Full distribution transparency is always achievable without any performance costs.
Grid computing is primarily targeted at enterprise computing.
Amazon EC2 is an example of Platform as a Service (PaaS).
Google App Engine is an example of Software as a Service (SaaS).
Software as a Service (SaaS) delivers software applications over the internet on a subscription basis.
Platform as a Service (PaaS) provides virtualized computing resources over the internet.
The evolution of cloud computing began with the invention of the personal computer.
Which of the following is a characteristic of public cloud deployment?

options.B: Hosted by third-party providers and shared among multiple users
options.D: Shared by multiple organizations with similar needs

questions.question_text: What is the primary advantage of a private cloud?
Which cloud deployment model combines public and private clouds?
Which of the following is an example of a public cloud provider?
What is the primary benefit of server virtualization?
Which technology is used to achieve server virtualization?
Which of the following is an example of network virtualization?
What is the main advantage of network virtualization?
Public cloud deployment is cost-effective and scalable.
Private cloud deployment is shared among multiple users.
Hybrid cloud combines public and private clouds.
AWS (Amazon Web Services) is an example of a private cloud provider.
Server virtualization allows multiple virtual machines to run on a single physical server.
Storage virtualization improves data redundancy and disaster recovery.
Virtual LANS (VLANs) are an example of network virtualization.
The primary advantage of virtualization is reduced hardware costs and improved resource utilization.
What is a hypervisor also known as?
Which type of hypervisor runs directly on the host hardware?
Which of the following is an example of a Type 2 hypervisor?
Which cloud service provider is the most mature and widely adopted?
Which AWS service is used for relational databases?
What is SageMaker service used for in AWS?
Which layer of cloud architecture includes hypervisors and virtual machines?
Type 2 hypervisors run directly on the host hardware.
True or False: Docker is an example of a Type 1 hypervisor.
True or False: AWS offers over 200 services.
True or False: Rekognition is an AWS service for image and video analysis.
What is the primary goal of resource management in cloud computing?

options.A: To increase the cost of cloud services
options.B: To allocate and optimize computing resources efficiently
options.C: To reduce the number of users accessing the cloud
options.D: To limit the scalability of applications

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a key characteristic of scalability in cloud computing?

options.A: It ensures that the system cannot grow or shrink.
options.B: It is a design feature that allows the system to handle an increased workload.
options.C: It limits the performance of the system.
options.D: It requires manual intervention for all scaling operations.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a type of scalability in cloud computing?
What is the primary function of a load balancer in cloud computing?

options.A: To increase the load on a single server
options.B: To distribute incoming network traffic across multiple servers
options.C: To reduce the performance of the system
options.D: To limit the number of users accessing the system

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a prerequisite for live VM migration?

options.A: The source and destination servers must have different hardware configurations.
options.B: The source and destination servers must run different versions of the hypervisor.
options.C: The source and destination servers must have access to the same storage system.
options.D: The source and destination servers must be on different networks.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a disadvantage of post-copy live migration?

options.B: It is suitable for VMs with high memory write activity.
options.C: It can cause performance degradation due to demand paging.
options.D: It does not require iterative copying of dirty pages.

questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of Kubernetes in cloud computing?

options.B: To automate the deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications
options.C: To reduce the scalability of applications
options.D: To increase the cost of cloud services

questions.question_text: Elasticity in cloud computing refers to the ability to scale resources up or down based on demand.
Multi-tenancy in cloud computing ensures that each user has a completely isolated infrastructure.
Vertical scaling involves adding more instances of resources, such as servers, to a cluster.
Load balancers in cloud computing are used to increase the load on a single server.
Live VM migration requires the source and destination servers to have different hardware configurations.
Pre-copy live migration is suitable for VMs with high memory write activity.
Post-copy live migration involves transferring memory pages on-demand from the source host.
Kubernetes is an open-source platform that automates the deployment and scaling of containerized applications.
Terraform is a tool used for declarative configuration management in cloud computing.
What is the primary purpose of data replication in distributed systems?

options.B: To improve reliability, performance, and fault tolerance
options.C: To eliminate the need for backups

questions.question_text: Which type of replication ensures all replicas execute the same sequence of operations?
What is a key characteristic of Quorum-Based Replication?

options.A: It requires all replicas to respond before acknowledging a write
options.B: It uses a subset of servers (quorum) to approve operations
options.C: It only works in single-node systems
options.D: It eliminates the need for consistency checks

questions.question_text: What is a drawback of Eventual Consistency?

options.D: Requires manual conflict resolution for every read

questions.question_text: Which consistency model ensures that a client always sees its writes, even if others see stale data?
Which consistency model guarantees that all nodes see the most recent write immediately?
Replication in distributed systems is primarily used to reduce storage costs.
State Machine Replication ensures all replicas execute the same sequence of operations.
In Primary-Backup replication, if the primary fails, the system stops functioning permanently.
Quorum-based replication requires approval from all servers for every operation.
Eventual Consistency guarantees that all replicas will eventually converge to the same state if no new updates are made.
Strong Consistency is ideal for systems where high availability is more important than up-to-date data.
Read-Your-Writes Consistency ensures that all clients see the latest writes immediately.
What is the primary goal of scheduling in cloud computing?

options.B: To map jobs to VMs and allocate resources efficiently

questions.question_text: What is the main characteristic of Round Robin scheduling?

options.A: Tasks are executed based on priority
options.B: Tasks are assigned in a cyclic order with a fixed time quantum
options.D: Tasks are randomly assigned to resources

questions.question_text: Which scheduling algorithm executes tasks in the order they arrive?
Which scheduling algorithm prioritizes tasks with the shortest execution time?
What is a key advantage of Priority Scheduling?

options.A: Ensures all tasks get equal time

questions.question_text: What problem can occur in Priority Scheduling if not managed properly?
Round Robin scheduling guarantees that no task monopolizes resources.
FCFS scheduling is optimal for minimizing waiting time for all tasks.
SJF scheduling always results in the lowest average waiting time.
Priority Scheduling cannot be combined with FCFS for tasks of equal priority.
Energy-Aware Scheduling optimizes for performance only.
Response time includes only the time a task spends executing, not waiting.
Workflow Scheduling is used for tasks with dependencies.
What is the primary goal of fault tolerance in cloud computing?

options.B: To ensure continuous operation despite faults
options.D: To eliminate the need for maintenance

questions.question_text: Which of these represents the root cause of a system problem?
Which type of failure occurs when a component fails to transmit an expected message?
What is an example of a hardware failure?
Which failure classification focuses on how a system fails?
What type of failure occurs when a system returns incorrect data?
Which of these is NOT a stage in the failure progression chain?
A fault always immediately results in a system failure.
Cloud fault tolerance helps maintain data confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
Receive omission occurs when a system fails to send an expected message.
A Byzantine failure involves predictable system behavior.
Network failures can include entire data center outages.
Fault tolerance is only concerned with hardware failures.
An unhandled exception in Java code would be classified as a software failure.
Timing failures occur when systems meet all their deadlines.
Component-centric classification helps engineers debug system issues.
What is the primary purpose of reactive fault tolerance approaches?

options.A: To predict failures before they occur
options.B: To minimize the impact of failures after they happen
options.C: To completely eliminate all system faults
options.D: To reduce hardware costs in cloud systems

questions.question_text: Which technique involves saving a system's state periodically to enable recovery from failures?
Which proactive fault tolerance approach involves periodic system reboots?
What does the process pairs approach in redundancy involve?

options.B: A primary process with a backup that takes over if needed

questions.question_text: Which metric measures the average time between inherent system failures?
What is the goal of pre-emptive migration in proactive fault tolerance?

options.A: To wait until failures occur before taking action
options.B: To move applications from unhealthy nodes before failures happen
options.C: To reduce the number of virtual machines in use

questions.question_text: Reactive fault tolerance approaches are used to predict failures before they occur.
Checkpointing prevents the loss of useful computation by saving system states periodically.
In task resubmission, failed tasks are always resubmitted to the same resource.
Software rejuvenation involves periodic system reboots to maintain stability.
The TMR approach requires five identical processes running in parallel.
Load balancing helps distribute CPU and memory usage across systems.
Forward error recovery involves rolling back to a previous checkpoint.
Self-healing systems can recover from failures without human intervention.
